data.title: Armstrong World Industries: Solid Growth Momentum And Upgraded Guidance (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Investment action

I had a hold rating for Armstrong World Industries (AWI) previously, as I thought the valuation was too expensive—so much so that there is very little room for error. My view has changed. While the valuation multiple is still high, I now believe multiples could continue staying at this level given the growth momentum, upgraded guidance, and tangible catalysts.

Q3 earnings

AWI reported a strong Q3 that really changed my mind on the business and outlook. Total net sales grew 10% y/y to $425.2 million, setting a new third-quarter high. The Mineral Fiber [MF] segment saw 6.2% y/y growth, driving sales to $274 million. While most of the growth came from favorable pricing and mix ($14 million contribution), volume contributed too, which was positive as this marks the second consecutive quarter of positive volume growth. And this does signal that the demand backdrop is recovering. As for the Architectural Specialties [AS] segment, it remained as the core growth driver, with net sales up 17.6% y/y to $151.2 million. To be fair, ~$16 million came from the 3form and Zahner acquisitions, but even if we adjust for these, organic sales still grew $7 million, or 6% y/y, and this is despite tougher comps. Margins were the only negative takeaway here. Consolidated adj. EBITDA margin contracted 120 bps to 34.7%, with both MF and AS seeing margin contraction. Anyway, I don’t think much attention should be paid to this margin pressure since the real takeaway is the 13.3% y/y EPS growth to $2.05.

Growth Accelerates, Justifying the Premium

When I last covered AWI, my hold rating was driven almost entirely by valuation. The stock looked expensive, and I wasn’t convinced there was enough room for upside surprise. After seeing the 3Q25 results and, more importantly, the upgraded outlook, I believe I have been too conservative previously. It seems clearer to me that the AWI growth story is actually getting much better, which justifies its premium multiple.

The key update here, I think, is management’s decision to raise FY2025 adj. EPS guidance. The new guide calls for a range of $7.45–$7.55, which implies 18%–20% y/y growth. Management also effectively dismissed the bear case (poor volume demand) for the MF segment by calling the market stabilizing and raising the FY2025 volume outlook. Remember that Q3 ended on 30th September, and the results came out just yesterday, which means management already had one full month of data (for Q4). This makes the volume guide credible.

Aside from the guide, AWI’s digital strategy continues to show its worth. I said before that this is a competitive edge, and AWI proved me right this quarter. The new highlight this quarter is Kanopi, an e-commerce platform that saw record sales and EBITDA. This is noteworthy because it confirms AWI’s ability to reach smaller and previously underserved customers profitably. The keyword is profitably, because anyone can chase after volume by heavily subsidizing it, but doing it profitably means that AWI has built a platform that can efficiently handle these smaller customers’ orders (low-volume orders, so it is hard to make the unit economics work vs. a large-volume order, as fixed cost is spread over a smaller base). From a growth perspective, this means AWI's growth runway has extended longer, as it can now go after the long tail of demand (e.g., demand from smaller contractors that typically require more niche products). Or you can just think of this as AWI expanding its total addressable market.

Meanwhile, the ProjectWorks design platform continues to gain traction as I expected. For recap, my general view was that ProjectWorks simplifies complex designs and installations, and that makes the life of architects easier, which drives adoption. However, it seems like I am missing a part of the story. Management noted another benefit that I thought was very bullish. This ProjectWorks design platform doesn’t just make the life of architects easier; it also addresses the problem of labor shortages in construction. By automating design rules and stepping up the pace of iterations, ProjectWorks actually increases productivity for contractors as well. Rather than directly reducing the number of labor contractors needed, it drives efficiency by reducing “wasted attempts.” Better design rules and iterations result in precise bills of materials that reduce the frequency of rework.

Another potential growth catalyst is the office segment, which represents ~30% of AWI’s total demand. Most readers would know that the office segment has been a drag on the business ever since Covid (more work-from-home policy that reduces the need for office spaces). However, we may have reached an inflection point. For the first time in seven years, US office vacancy rates have moved lower (per a third-party data cited by management during the call). This is too early to call it a recovery trend, but it does support the narrative of the ongoing return-to-office trend. AWI is already seeing early benefits, with increasing tenant improvement projects in its order flow. Tenants wouldn’t spend capex to improve if they are not seeing improving end demand. In my view, this could be a meaningful swing factor. Even if the office market simply stabilizes, it removes an overhang on the stock, and in the bull case, if it becomes a tailwind, it could unlock incremental volume and operating leverage.

Balance sheet and capital allocation

On the balance sheet, I don’t see much of a problem for AWI to continue reinvesting for growth. The business is generating a good amount of cash (adj. free cash flow is up 22% year-to-date), allowing it to fund growth without tapping hard into leverage. In fact, the business is generating so much cash that in Q3 alone, management raised its dividend by 10%, repurchased $27 million of stock, and even did a bolt-on acquisition (bought Geometrik for $7.5 million). I am not incorporating this into my base case, but there is a potential for AWI to re-lever up its balance sheet back to the historical leverage ratio (>1x EBITDA) and return that cash to shareholders.

Valuation

My view on the stock has changed for the better. I think there is a good chance that AWI will continue to grow as low-teens (FY25 13% was guided), and if we keep margins flat, earnings could grow to $470 million in FY28, and that solid growth (relatively better than peers, as shown below) should continue to justify multiples to stay at the current premium elevated level (23x forward PE vs. peers with an average of 12x). While I noted that the last time this happened, the multiples re-rated downwards quickly, I think this time may be different. There are visible growth catalysts that could continue to support growth. Also note that the recovery in the office segment could elevate growth higher.

Risk

There are execution risks that could hurt growth. Specifically, the AS segment growth still depends on successfully integrating 3form and Zahner, which are currently weighing on segment margins. If the synergies are lower than expected, earnings growth could be weaker than I expected. On costs, about $6 million in Q3 operating expenses were one-off expenses that management called out as timing-related, and we should see a sequential improvement in cost. The risk here is that ongoing inflation, especially in energy prices, could mask this “improvement,” and the market may inch closer to being conservative when modelling margins (I am modelling flat; they may model declining margins).

Conclusion

I am upgrading my rating on AWI to buy. My previous view that valuation was too high is no longer the case given the growth momentum and raised guidance. The digital strategy also continues to work, with Kanopi and ProjectWorks showing tangible results. There is also the office space segment that is finally showing signs of inflecting into a tailwind. All in all, I can bridge to a nice upside case if AWI can continue to grow at low teens with a 20% net margin.

data.title: Alphabet: Growth, Buybacks, Cheap P/E
data.description:
Alphabet (GOOG) reported better-than-expected earnings for its third fiscal quarter on Wednesday amid strong, double-digit growth in its core Search and Cloud businesses. While Search advertising contributed nicely to the company’s top line growth in Q3, the real story for Google is the expansion of its operating income in its Cloud segment which is driven by accelerating AI product adoption.

Google previously said that it was boosting its capital spending in a bid to accelerate the growth in its AI and Cloud businesses, and the tech enterprise raised its CapEx guidance again. With demand for AI products increasing, I remain optimistic that Google is in a strong position to grow its earnings and free cash flow going forward. Google's shares are the second-cheapest, after Meta Platforms (META), in the big tech industry group and have revaluation upside, in my opinion.

Previous rating

I rated shares of Alphabet as a strong buy -- Chrome Ruling Is A Game Changer -- due to the tech platform recently receiving a favorable Chrome ruling that allowed Google to keep its important and highly profitable web browser business. Further, Cloud is showing material growth momentum, both in terms of revenue and operating income, and since shares are still cheap, I confirm my strong buy rating for Google following the Q3'25 report.

Google beat Q3’25 estimates by large margins

The tech enterprise beat consensus estimates on both the top and bottom line for the September quarter: it reported normalized earnings of $3.09 per-share which out-matched the consensus EPS estimate by $0.83. The top line came in at $102.4B, out-matching the average prediction by $2.2B amid a strong Cloud and digital advertising performance.

Strong Cloud operating income growth

The main story for Google, now and in the future, will be Google Cloud which benefits from growing demand for AI products in a market that is funneling hundres of billions of dollars annually into the Data Center market. As more workloads shift to the Cloud and companies are willing to spend more money on AI products and services in order to grow their businesses, realize cost efficiencies and improve productivity, Google’s Cloud Platform is in a robust position to make growing operating income contributions to the company’s financial results.

In Q3'25, Google generated $102.3B in revenue, showing 16% year-over-year growth. Google Search, which represents 55% of consolidated revenue in Q3, benefited from a strong digital advertising market: here, Alphabet generated 15% year-over-year revenue growth and achieved a total of $56.6B in revenues. The firm's total operating income reached $31.2B, showing 10% year-over-year growth.

Cloud is where all the action is for Google, despite the segment being only 27% the size of Alphabet's Search business (based off of Q3'25 revenue contributions). Google Cloud generated $15.2B in revenue, showing 34% year-over-year growth and the segment saw a significant operating margin upswing compared to the year-earlier period as well: Cloud generated $3.6B in total operating income (+85% Y/Y) which calculates to an operating income margin of 23.7% (+6.6 PP Y/Y). The Cloud segment's operating income is therefore growing ~8.9X faster than its consolidated operating income.

In the third fiscal quarter, Google remained widely profitable, which is mainly due to the earnings consistency in the Search business. The tech enterprise generated free cash flow in the amount of $24.5B in Q3'25, showing 38.7% year-over-year growth, meaning the company's free cash flow grew more than twice as fast at the company's revenues. Google achieved a free cash flow margin of 23.9% in the third-quarter, showing a margin expansion of 3.9 PP compared to the year-earlier period.

$millions Q3'24 Q4'24 Q1'25 Q2'25 Q3'25 Y/Y Growth
Revenues $88,268 $96,469 $90,234 $96,428 $102,346 15.9%
Net cash provided by operating activities $30,698 $39,113 $36,150 $27,747 $48,414 57.7%
Less: purchases of property and equipment ($13,061) ($14,276) ($17,197) ($22,446) ($23,953) 83.4%
Free cash flow $17,637 $24,837 $18,953 $5,301 $24,461 38.7%
Free cash flow margin 20.0% 25.7% 21.0% 5.5% 23.9% 19.6%

Source: Author

These numbers highlight a very well-performing core business -- Search and Cloud -- and with operating income and free cash flows surging, Google is in a great position to return more cash to investors in the future.

In the third-quarter, the tech platform spent $11.5B on stock buybacks and $40.2B year-to-date. And more stock buybacks are likely to get executed in Q4... which should especially benefit the Search business given the inclusion of the holiday period. Going forward, I expect Google to invest more money into:

  1. The development of new AI-driven products, such as AI queries, which are integrated into Search and Cloud and which accelerate Google's growth in the core business
  2. Data Centers in order to accommodate soaring demand for AI-driven workloads. In this regard, Google just raised its FY 2025 CapEx outlook from $85.0B to a new range of $91-93B and the company has guided for a significant CapEx boost next year.
  3. Stock buybacks. The tech company may boost its stock authorization next year and potentially increase its buyback size (from a current $70B authorization) if free cash flow performance remain strong
  4. The acquisition of AI start-ups. In order to accelerate its AI-centric growth strategy in Search and Cloud, Google may turn to a more acquisition-focused approach to boosting its top line growth.

Google’s valuation

In the past, I recommended Alphabet chiefly because the company was the cheapest big tech stock, despite delivering double-digit top line growth and being highly profitable. Shares of Alphabet are currently trading at a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 25.7X, but are still relatively cheap compared to other big tech companies in the industry group... many of whom trade a significantly higher earnings multipliers.

As revaluation catalysts for Google I see 1) Accelerating AI spending in the enterprise market which could drive results in Cloud especially, 2) Expanding operating income profitability, driven by AI product up-take in Cloud, and 3) Strength in digital advertising spending backing up the firm’s largest segment (Search), especially in the fourth-quarter... which is typically a strong one for companies selling digital ads.

In my opinion, shares of Alphabet could revalue to a ~30X P/E ratio fairly easily... under the condition that Alphabet continues to grow at double-digit rates and CapEx spending in the enterprise market doesn’t slow. Google is currently expected to generate $10.73 per-share in earnings in FY 2026, implying 8% Y/Y growth, which calculates to a fair value of $322 per-share.

Risks with Google

The biggest risk for Alphabet, as I see it, relates to a potential slowdown in AI-driven CapEx spending in the enterprise market which could hurt the company’s growth momentum in the Cloud business. What would therefore potentially negatively impact my bullish view on the technology firm is if the firm's stellar Cloud-driven growth moderated or if Google saw a deterioration of its free cash flow margins.

The firm's strong FCF is key to Google's AI-driven CapEx ramp as well as stock buybacks, so any deterioration in the fundamentals of the core digital advertising market is likely going to have a severe valuation impact on Google's stock outlook.

Final thoughts

Google has received a steady stream of positive results in the last several months including a favorable court ruling regarding its Chrome browser which pushed shares into a new up-leg.... and now the company has submitted an earnings scorecard that crushed Wall Street's estimates.

Google is well-positioned as one of the largest public Cloud platforms to cash in on AI-driven Cloud growth and the company is seeing impressive operating income growth. Google's strong Q3 earnings report highlighted robust growth momentum in both Search and Cloud and strength in free cash flows... which is likely going to add to investors' already positive sentiment about the company. After the earnings report, shares of Google soared 7% in the after-hours market, but I see more room for shares to appreciate.

data.title: C.H. Robinson: Margin Gains Impress (Downgrade)
data.description:
Shares of C.H. Robinson Worldwide (CHRW) have been a solid performer over the past year, gaining 20%. Despite tariffs and trade frictions, CHRW’s capital-light model has delivered strong results for shareholders. The good news continued on Thursday as shares rallied another 10+% following strong earnings Wednesday after the bell. Since I last covered shares in April, CHRW has rallied over 50%, justifying my “Buy” rating and exceeding my expectations. With updated financials, now is a good time to revisit C.H. Robinson.

In the company’s third quarter, C.H. Robinson earned $1.41 per share, beating estimates by $0.11, even as revenue declined by 11% to $4.1 billion. Adjusted gross profit was down a more modest 4%, while income from operations actually grew by 23% thanks to significant cost discipline. Global shipping rates continue to fall, driving the revenue decline, and Europe has also been a source of weakness. In contrast, CHRW continues to meaningfully gain market share in the United States, boosting revenue. As noted on the earnings call, freight activity has weakened for 12 straight quarters, with Q3 the worst Q3 since 2009. CHRW’s solid results in this macro backdrop speak to its continued market share gains, as well as its extremely impressive cost management.

CHRW gains share and margins in U.S. trucking

North American Surface Transportation (“NAST”) is its largest segment, accounting for about 63% of firmwide gross profit. Volumes grew by 3%, and operating margins expanded for an eighth straight quarter to 39%, approaching its 40% mid-cycle target. Both Truckload and LTL (“less than truckload”) were up about 3%. CHRW estimates that the market declined by 7% in the quarter, so we are seeing the company’s investments in technology meaningfully expand its market share. Adjusted gross profit rose by 6% to $444 million.

CHRW generated 8% more gross profit per LTL order while it held gross profit flat per truckload order, a resilient performance despite pricing pressure. The ability to gain market share while also enhancing margins continues to be impressive. As you can see below, gross margins have been steadily increasing and are essentially at the highest level since before COVID. However, the dollar value of gross profit per shipment remains depressed, just given the weakness in the U.S. trucking market. If we eventually see an upturn in the trucking market, there should be meaningful gross profit upside. Unfortunately, given sluggish economic activity, I do not see this occurring within the next 12 months.

Tariffs weigh on ocean freight

Global Forwarding margins expanded 380bps from last year. Still, the weak global shipping environment is weighing as tariffs reduce trade volume. As a result, gross profit fell by 18% from last year, as ocean volumes fell by 7% and air declined by 10%. As you can see below, the majority of this business is tied to ocean freight, and that market is extremely challenged, with gross profit down by nearly a third to $111 million. The ongoing conflict in the Red Sea also has forced vessel rerouting along more expensive and time-consuming routes, a structural challenge that appears unlikely to end soon.

As a result, gross profit per ocean shipment fell by 27%. Gross profit per air shipment rose by 17%, helping to offset volume declines, and mix shift led to a 31% jump in gross profit per customs transaction. Still, these segments are too small to offset pressure in Ocean freight, and I expect global trade activity to remain muted.

That said, aside from stronger earnings, sentiment around CHRW is likely being boosted this morning by the conciliatory U.S.-China meeting overnight whereby the United States agreed to tariff rates of 47% from 57%, and China agreed to delay rare earth export controls. Tariff rates are still high, which will continue to greatly restrict U.S.-China trade in my view. All else equal, increased trade between the U.S. & China will benefit CHRW’s business, so the fact that the two countries chose de-escalation over escalation is a positive.

Cost performance impresses

Its Lean AI initiative continues to deliver cost efficiencies. The company continues to increase its use of “AI agents” to provide quotes, take orders, connect with carriers, and manage payments. By continuing to automate tasks that were previously done manually by employees, we are seeing the company generate meaningful savings. In fact, average employee headcount is down nearly 11% from last year, and operating expenses fell by 13% to $485 million. CHRW’s technology spending is creating clear efficiency savings.

During the quarter, CHRW bought back $115 million of stock. The company maintains an excellent balance sheet with just 1.2x debt/EBITDA leverage and ~$1.2 billion of long-term debt. With leverage coming down, management expects more share repurchases over the next year. Between its dividend and buyback, I expect at least $600 million of capital returns next year, or at least $5.50/share. Aside from buybacks, CHRW pays a 1.9% dividend yield.

So far this year, the company has generated $554 million of free cash flow. Back in April, I was targeting $550-$650 million of free cash flow. With margin performance exceeding my expectations and the tariff outcome not as bad as feared in April, I now see CHRW generating about $670-$720 million of free cash flow this year, depending on working capital movements, or about $6 per share.

Valuation prices in the good news

Alongside results, management boosted its 2026 outlook by $50 million to $965 million to $1.04 billion, representing about $6 per share in EPS in an environment where there is zero end-market growth. While 0% growth does not usually seem like an optimistic assumption, that would be a marked improvement from this year. While much of the tariff headwind should already be in results, I see limited scope for volume growth. The company sees about $120 million of savings benefits next year, driving much of its operating income growth.

At ~$145 pre-market, shares are trading ~24x 2026 earnings and have about a 4% free cash flow yield. Frankly, I am cautious about the freight market turning positive next year. While we may have passed peak tariff pressures, economic activity remains muted. Plus, with NAST approaching mid-cycle levels even in a down market, I suspect that the majority of the margin gains have already occurred. After today’s rally, shares appear to be pricing in the good news. That said, with trade sentiment improvement and buybacks likely to accelerate, the environment should remain favorable towards CHRW. As such, I am downgrading shares to a “Hold.” I see no rush to "Sell," but shares are pricing in much of the good news already.

data.title: Fresh Del Monte: Going Bananas Over This Stock, A Strong Dividend Opportunity
data.description:
The Stock: An Earnings Beat This Week By Major Foods Brand

To change up from my usual focus on REITs, tech, and financials, today I am compelled to write about an entirely different sector as food company Fresh Del Monte Produce Inc. (FDP) beat normalized EPS estimates by an impressive $0.19 during its earnings this week.

I first recognized the future value of this stock back in my July article when I called it a Buy, and since then, the stock is up +1.2%, with yet another earnings beat.

A key driver of my bullish sentiment was continued global demand for fresh fruits and vegetables. Along those lines, if you are just tuning in to my coverage for the first time, consider this company

"produces, markets, and distributes fresh and fresh-cut fruits and vegetables in North America, Central America, South America, Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Asia, and internationally,"

according to its Seeking Alpha profile.

To get a "taste" for their product portfolio, in their North America assortment they have something called a HoneyGlow pineapple:

The goal of today's updated research was to see if my prior rating stands, in the wake of this week's earnings data. After my analysis, I determined that Fresh Del Monte continues to be a Buy, so I'm reaffirming my summer rating.

My thesis today argues that this firm's diversified portfolio across the fruit/vegetable/produce segment can help meet future market demand for basic staples globally. It also presents a low balance sheet risk and is a proven dividend grower, in addition to forecasts pointing to over +20% further upside potential, despite some headwinds from margins and macroeconomic challenges in this sector.

Rating Score: Buy

The following worksheet summarizes the factors that led to my score and support my thesis:

Growth Factors: A Mixed Top-Line Picture Impacted By Multiple Macro Factors

As mentioned, the company just published its Q3 2025 results this week, and so in this section we will focus on the topic of growth factors.

In terms of revenue, to get a sense of where lies both momentum and challenges, we can see from the Q3 presentation (pg 8) that net sales were slightly impacted (down about 2% YoY) by the vegetable segment, but also saw favorable movement in the fresh fruit and pineapple lines:

A key segment of theirs, bananas, had a mixed picture, as the investor presentation (pg 9) showed that even though net sales roles YoY it was driven more by price increases rather than higher sales volume across the board:

So, what we can learn from these few data points, thinking about the future of this company and its stock, is that it is a business impacted by market demand for fruits and vegetables but also price fluctuations in those.

On a macro level, some data, such as that of Statista, shows favorable future revenue growth in the banana segment:

Revenue in the Bananas market amounts to US$166.95bn in 2025. The market is expected to grow annually by 7.07% (CAGR 2025-2030).

If this +7% CAGR forecast comes true, I think it could certainly be an upside factor for firms like this one.

In addition, when it comes to certain fruits like bananas, FDP fills a demand that simply cannot be produced in certain parts of the world due to unfavorable climate. For instance, SA analyst Waterside Insight pointed out in their July article on this firm:

Almost 80% of its sales go to North America and Europe, where these fruits are not suitable to grow locally, except for the southern part of the US and Mexico.

Nevertheless, the laws of supply and demand impact this industry, as an oversupply of any fruit or vegetable could be a future downside for a company like this, whereas a shortage could work in its favor. Investors should consider that dynamic when considering this sector. For example, back in 2016, Australian news highlighted how past cyclones caused a banana shortage:

Most banana growers took a big hit and there was not much supply around, so the growers who did have supply, they made a lot of money.

For now, forward revenue growth for this firm is expected to be a mere +1.2%, 55% below its sector average, so that certainly could be a concern to investors putting more weight on the top line results:

So, given all the points raised in this section, I think it is justified to take a firm neutral stance in the category of growth.

Profitability: One-Time Hit to Q3 Profits, But Consensus EPS Outlook Is Favorable

Going beyond the top-line, and considering the firm beat its Q3 normalized EPS estimates, here we'll talk about the topic of profitability since there is more to that story.

It is important to mention that on a GAAP basis the firm actually reported a net loss for Q3, however when looking more closely at the Q3 press release it shows that this was largely driven by "asset impairment and other charges" that caused a negative operating income:

The firm happens to be going through the process of divesting one of its businesses, Mann Packing, and in Q3 commentary the company said the impairment charge was:

"related to underperforming banana farms in the Philippines and the impairment charges associated with the planned divestiture of Mann Packing."

Financial sites like Investopedia have confirmed that such charges can impact GAAP results, and we see that to be the case here, rather than ongoing core business operations being the cause.

So, for this reason I also think it's necessary to consider margins rather than just one-time quarterly results, and compare to peers.

A core earnings margin, the EBITDA margin, is 5.8% for this firm, compared to a sector average of 13.4%.

As for 3 peers, I picked ones that are publicly-traded in the U.S. and are active in the fruit/vegetable/produce segment: Dole (DOLE), Mission Produce (AVO), and Calavo Growers (CVGW), because I think investors and other analysts will be curious how efficient FDP is compared to similar businesses.

In this comparison, data is rather favorable for FDP as only Mission Produce beats its EBITDA margin, while FDP leads the group in net income margin.

If such trends can continue or even improve, that could drive favorable upside for FDP.

In a year dominated often by financial headlines surrounding tariffs, and considering there is always ongoing uncertainty over that topic as it seems for a global business like this who does a lot of importing and exporting the consensus outlook for earnings is favorable, with 12-13% YoY EPS growth expected this year and next.

So, in consideration of these multiple points above, I am going with a cautious buy rating in this category.

Balance Sheet & Credit Ratings: Several Data Points That Are Positive Factors

Next, moving past the world of revenue and profits let's talk somewhat about the balance sheet.

Although it has a very similar name, Fresh Del Monte Produce is not the same company as Del Monte Foods, who CNN reported as having filed for bankruptcy this summer, so it is pertinent to distinguish the two.

Further, I did not find any recent credit ratings on FDP from major agencies, so in lieu of that coverage I think comparing its debt-to-equity vs peers is a good metric:

The good news from this data above is that FDP has a D/E ratio of just 0.18, among the lowest in this peer group, and indicative of very low leverage risk in relation to equity.

I believe a low leverage exposure is particularly a positive sign in high interest rate environments where debt is costly, although a balance is needed too since too much over-reliance just on equity and no borrowing can sometimes lead to dilution of share value, if a company funds itself by keep issuing new shares.

Another valuable metric is the quick ratio, showing whether liquid assets can cover short-term liabilities.

Using a benchmark of 1.0 or better, FDP passes this test by having a quick ratio of 1.01, in fact on the higher end of this peer group, and yet another positive factor in favor of this firm.

I also would like to point out that from Q3 commentary this week the firm has been making an effort to get rid of some underperforming assets:

We took decisive actions to optimize our portfolio and drive long-term profitability by exiting underperforming banana operations in the Philippines and divesting Mann Packing. These strategic moves simplify our operations, sharpen our focus on higher-margin, higher-growth categories, and position us to deliver stronger earnings and sustained value for our shareholders.

So, this could also drive future upside as the firm pivots to focus on assets that have better returns.

For the combined reasons above, I am taking a stronger bullish stance in this category, than in the prior few where I was neutral or lukewarm.

Cashflow & Dividend Trends: A Proven Dividend Growth, And Share Buybacks

As this is a dividend paying stock, investors will want to know what kind of dividend trends there are and also the cashflow trends to support the dividend.

Yield-focused investors will like the 3.5% yield which is above its sector average, while growth-driven investors will be interested to know that this stock's 10 year dividend CAGR is above average at 8.6%, despite seeing some headwinds in 2019:

Although this data relies on historic, past-looking results, it could indicate that this is a serious and established firm that has recovered nicely from the 2020 pandemic era and shown resilience, able to grow its dividend over a longer period.

If that trend line continues as show in the chart, investors can anticipate further dividend growth.

A cashflow metric tied to the core business, the operating cashflow growth, was at +4.8%, above its sector average, and shows the core business is able to grow cash.

Further, Q3 data (investor presentation, pg 12) shows that this firm has an active share repurchase program which I think is a positive factor as it commits cash to buying its own shares, potentially boosting their value:

Given the multiple points above, I am bullish in this category as well, and I think this boosts the overall rating score significantly.

Valuation & Share Price Trends: Mildly Undervalued with +24% Price Upside Expected

We've now come to the part where I discuss valuation and price trends, and notable to mention is that despite all the media focusing on tariffs and their impacts on any business involved in global trade, we can see FDP has been resilient with its stock price coming close to the 1-year price return of the overall S&P 500 Index (SP500):

Further, we can see from the price chart I made below that this stock has shown bullishness this entire year as it continually trades above its 200-day simple moving average:

At the same time, though, other data points to some undervaluation vs. its sector. Seeking Alpha data shows a forward P/E (GAAP) of just 12.71, vs. the sector avg of 18.02.

The non-GAAP forward earnings multiple is very similar, so no need to really mention it as it is not a major outlier.

This is a great example of a stock that is mildly undervalued but also is trading above its averages, so keep in mind that on the one hand it could indicate market demand for this sector which can be seen as one that provides consumer staple necessities (fruits & vegetables) that is a major part of the daily consumer grocery list, but on the other hand it is a business with relatively low margins compared to some sectors.

What moves the needle in favor of this stock is what the Wall St. consensus expects to be a further +34% upside to the share price. My worksheet below summarizes this:

From this worksheet above, I expect an avg upside of +24% to the most recent price, when averaging my own price target with that of the Wall St. Consensus.

A 24% upside forecast definitely makes this an undervalued future value opportunity, moving the needle towards the buy column in this category, and boosting its overall rating.

Conclusion: Agree with Across-The-Board Bullish Consensus

To wrap up, today's research has shown why a Buy rating is justified, and so I'm agreeing with the consensus (quant rating, analysts, Wall St) that all seem to think this is either a buy or strong buy.

It is also being added to my dividend ideas for the month, due to above-average yield and proven 10 year dividend growth, but also proven cashflow growth to help support the dividend.

A risk to my bullish challenge not mentioned elsewhere in this article can come from a major sector risk and that is something like major impacts to actual crops, such as weather catastrophes and crop disease destroying tons of fruit and vegetables, not to mention food recalls due to evidence of contamination.

The company itself mentioned this as one of key risks, in their Q3 release, saying such risk includes:

factors outside our control that impact our and other growers’ crop quality and yields, such as severe weather conditions, crop disease, disruptions or issues that impact its production facilities or complex logistics network.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN even highlighted the risk of crop disease in an article:

A plant disease caused by a specific fungus called Fusarium wilt Tropical Race 4 (TR4) is spreading fast, damaging production in Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and Latin America. It poses a threat to large commercial producers as well as small-scale local production.

I believe a mitigating factor that could favor FDP is that it not only is diversified across multiple products (not just bananas) but also uses multiple farms and supply-chain networks globally, so those could mitigate some of this risk, as opposed to a company with a single farm and product whose crop gets wiped out and it cannot sell it to the market.

With that said, my call to action to readers, to conclude today's discussion, is to keep considering Fresh Del Monte if you want some portfolio exposure to this sector for the purpose of diversification, as well as a dividend income opportunity.

data.title: Crinetics Pharmaceuticals: Its Post-FDA Approval Future
data.description:
Shares of endocrine therapy concern Crinetics Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (CRNX) rallied approximately 25% in response to its first-ever FDA approval for Palsonify treating acromegaly on September 25, 2025. The green light opens up a market of $1.5 billion to $2.2 billion (2023) with a label expansion opportunity in carcinoid syndrome, for which the therapy should enter a Phase 3 study in 2H25. When I last looked at Crinetics nearly two years ago, the company was still a clinical-stage concern. Obviously, this has changed with the recent FDA approval and Crinetics now enters into the early commercialization stage.

With a second clinical program undergoing three pivotal trials for Cushing’s disease, as well as adult and pediatric congenital adrenal hyperplasia, Crinetics merited further investigation. An analysis follows below.

Company Overview:

Crinetics Pharmaceuticals, Inc. is a San Diego based early commercial-stage biotech concern focused on the development and marketing of therapies to treat rare endocrine diseases and endocrine-related tumors. The company has one recently approved product, Palsonify, which is in the clinic pursuing a second indication, as well as another program addressing two other hormonal conditions. Crinetics was formed in 2008 and went public in 2018, raising net proceeds of $106.5 million at $17 per share. Its stock trades around $42.00 a share, translating to a market cap of just less $4 billion.

The company’s development approach is to target endocrine indications with low patient populations and high unmet need where the clinical trials employ biomarkers (such as hormone levels) as primary endpoints with proof-of-concept established by solid pharmacokinetics in healthy patients during Phase 1 studies. Each of these trial characteristics promote lower clinical expenses.

Crinetics’ candidates are oral nonpeptide therapeutics that target peptide G protein-coupled receptors, which play a central role in the regulation of growth, energy, metabolism, GI function, stress, and nearly all aspects of homeostasis.

Palsonify

The company’s commercial product is Palsonify (paltusotine), a once-daily small molecule somatostatin receptor type 2 (SST2) agonist that was approved by the FDA for the treatment of acromegaly when surgical response is inadequate or surgery is not an option on September 25, 2025. The green light was granted on the strength of two Phase 3 clinical trials. In PATHFNDER-1, 83% of acromegaly patients whose condition was controlled on peptide somatostatin mimickers octreotide or lanreotide depot monotherapy maintained insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels ≤ 1.0 times the upper limit of normal versus placebo (4%) (p<0.0001). In PATHFNDR-2, the therapy achieved IGF-1 levels ≤ 1.0 times the upper limit of normal in 56% of treatment-naïve participants versus 5% for placebo (p<0.0001).

In both studies, Palsonify maintained or lowered seven key symptoms of acromegaly, which is typically triggered by a benign pituitary tumor causing excess growth hormone [GH] discharge, resulting in the over secretion of IGF-1 by the liver. Since both GH and IGF-1 promote tissue development, their overproduction results in giantism-like abnormal growth of hands and feet and changes in facial features. In addition to these outward physical manifestations, acromegaly can cause arthritis, carpal tunnel syndrome, changes in glucose and lipid metabolism, fatigue, organ enlargement, cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, skin odor, vision issues, and hypopituitarism. These symptoms contribute to increased mortality rates and lower quality of life.

The first treatment option for the ~36,000 Americans suffering with acromegaly (of which ~17,000 are undiagnosed) is surgery, which can be curative if the tumor is accessible for complete resection. If surgery is unsuccessful, pharmacological options include first-line generic somatostatin analogs, including the aforementioned octreotide and lanreotide. However, the efficacy of these once-monthly, physician-administered (intramuscular or deep subcutaneous) peptide injections is spotty, with approximately half of the ~4,000 patients on these therapies failing to achieve biochemical control or experiencing a return of symptoms by month’s end. Pfizer’s (PFE) Somavert (pegvisomant), a daily injectable GH receptor antagonist, is generally prescribed when these peptide therapies fail. An oral version of octreotide – Chiesi Farmaceutici’s twice-daily Mycappsa – was approved by the FDA in 2020 after 58% maintained their IGF-1 response versus 19% on placebo (p=0.008). However, its administration requires two fasting periods per day.

With clear superiority to Mycappsa and a significantly greater delivery advantage over the peptide and GH injections, Palsonify should rapidly become the go to treatment option in an admittedly crowded space when surgery is inadequate. Management believes that in addition to the ~1,500 newly diagnosed domestic patients per annum, there are currently ~11,000 diagnosed patients with high unmet need. An awareness program targeting the ~17,000 undiagnosed sufferers is part of an October 2025 launch, supported by a sales force of 36 and an annual price of $290,000. The EMA is expected to render a decision on its use across the pond in 1H26. News of the FDA sanctioning shot shares of CRNX 28% higher to $45.91 in the subsequent trading session.

The other indication being pursued by Crinetics’ approved therapy is carcinoid syndrome, an excessive secretion of serotonin that causes severe diarrhea and flushing that afflicts ~33,000 Americans. Caused by neuroendocrine tumors (NETs), the disorder, like acromegaly, is typically treated with injectable peptide somatostatin analogs. That said, in 2018, Novartis’ (NVS) Lutathera (lutetium Lu 177 dotatate), a radioligand (i.e., a drug that combines a therapeutic molecule with a radioactive particle) was approved by the FDA for the treatment of gastro-entero-pancreatic NETs after demonstrating a 79% reduction in the risk of disease progression or death versus standard of care in patients with unresectable NETs in the midgut region. Despite being administered through four IV injections over eight weeks and intramuscular injections every four weeks for 18 months, owing to the fact that its addressable domestic market is ~110,000 (out of a total NET population of ~175,000), Lutathera sales reached $724 million in 2024.

After reducing flushing frequency by 63% (n=24; p<0.0001) and excess bowl movements by 60% (n=16; p=0.02) in a Phase 2 trial, Palsonify is expected to enroll its first participant in a 141-patient, placebo-controlled Phase 3 study (CAREFNDR) with the prior study datapoints comprising the primary and key secondary endpoints (respectively) in 2H25.

Atumelnant

Crinetics other clinical asset is atumelnant, an oral nonpeptide adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) receptor agonist that is being investigated for the treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia [CAH] and ACTH-dependent Cushing’s Syndrome (ADCS). CAH is a set of genetic maladies resulting from poor cortisol synthesis, which engenders over secretion of ACTH with multiple downstream effects such as overproduction of testosterone, leading to excessive facial hair, abnormal menstrual cycles, acne, and/or life-threatening salt and fluid imbalances. The conditions afflicts ~27,000 Americans, of which ~17,000 would likely be eligible for atumelnant. ADCS is the result of an overactive pituitary gland or ectopic (i.e., outside the pituitary) tumors that produce excessive levels of ACTH. With an estimated domestic prevalence of 11,000, Crinetics believes that ~5,000 would be eligible for atumelnant treatment.

After demonstrating dose-dependent and statistically significant declines in morning serum androstenedione (A4) levels at week 12, atumelnant is set to be tested in three pivotal trials, including a Phase 2/3 study (BALANCE-CAH) in children and a Phase 3 trial (CALM-CAH) in adults – both with CAH – that should initiate in 2H25. A Phase 2/3 study for ADCS is expected to start in 1H26.

It should be noted that after seven decades without a new treatment option, Neurocrine Biosciences (NBIX) twice-daily, oral corticotropin-releasing factor type 1 receptor antagonist Crenessity (crinecerfont) won an approval from the FDA as an-add on to classic glucocorticoid replacement therapy for CAH in December 2024.

Balance Sheet & Analyst Commentary:

To finance its clinical and commercial ambitions, Crinetics held cash and securities of $1.20 billion on June 30, 2025, providing it an operating runway into 2029.

The Street is enamored by Crinetics’ prospects, as can be seen above. On average, sell-side analysts expect Palsonify to achieve blockbuster status by 2029 with sales of $1.19 billion.

Verdict:

Sporting a market cap of ~$2.8 billion net of current cash and sales projections of ~$1.2 billion in FY29, shares of CRNX would appear to have additional upside. That said, the market for acromegaly right now is not huge. Given that it is already a crowded treatment market, Palsonify is Crinetics’ first commercial rodeo, pivotal trials for other indications (carcinoid, adult CAH, pediatric CAH, and Cushing’s) are only set to initiate over the ensuing 12 months, and Crenessity’s head start in CAH, analysts’ FY29 mean outlook appears optimistic. As such, I expect a pullback after the recent runup on Palsonify’s approval. If CRNX comes back down to the mid-$30s, I will likely take an initial position in the stock via covered call orders. In the meantime, I will wait to see a couple of quarters of sales results to ascertain how the early stage marketing rollout is going for its newly approved treatment.

data.title: Futu Holdings: Focus On Q3 Preview And Policy Headwinds
data.description:
I've retained a "Hold" rating for Futu Holdings Limited (FUTU).

I find it difficult to be either strongly bullish or bearish after looking at regulatory issues and its third-quarter outlook.

The earlier May 29, 2025, article evaluated FUTU's 1Q25 showing and factors influencing future results.

Anticipating Robust Bottom-Line Expansion

The firm will disclose its upcoming quarterly numbers on Nov. 19.

FUTU's 2Q2025 normalized net profit was +105% higher on a YoY basis. My take is that it should have done similarly well in Jul-Sep '25, considering a number of indicators.

Both the "Hang Seng Index/HSI" and "Nasdaq Composite Index" (COMP:IND) rose by a low-teens percentage (source: S&P Capital IQ) in the 3rd quarter this year.

I see FUTU's end-Sep "assets under management" or "AUM" surpassing the HKD 1.1T mark, implying a 13% sequential growth.

The group's fee income for the recent three-month period was likely to be boosted by COMP:IND's and HSI's outperformance. It's natural to assume that investors' interest in U.S./HK equities remained strong. FUTU would have benefited from a resulting increase in trading commissions. Also, the pressure on its "net interest income" or "NII" should have eased substantially.

My late-May update mentioned FUTU "places customers' unused cash in HKD-denominated deposits, which is an important source of finance earnings." I noted then that "the 1M-HIBOR (One-Month Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate) has fallen by approximately 360 bps (basis points) to below 0.6%."

As per S&P Capital IQ data, the 1M-HIBOR recovered to above 3% in September 2025.

FUTU's 2Q25 NII jumped 19% quarter-on-quarter. At the analyst briefing, it explained that a rise in "cash positions within their (clients') portfolios" more than offset "meaningful HIBOR declines." Its interest income outlook has become brighter now.

Separately, its operations related to digital assets probably had a good performance in the latest quarter. CoinGecko's data suggests that the "average daily volume" or "ADV" for "HashKey" grew three-fifths higher QoQ for 3Q25. The latter is an exchange used by FUTU to provide "cryptocurrency trading" according to a "South China Morning Post" commentary piece.

I'm predicting that the enterprise will announce a doubling of non-GAAP earnings from 3Q24's HK$1,398 million to 3Q2025's HK$2.8 billion next month. This also translates into a 5% improvement sequentially.

But Policy-Related Changes Are An Issue

The regulatory authorities' actions can have a big impact on companies operating in the financial sector like FUTU.

Recent news flow has gotten me worried about the group's prospects for the final quarter of '25 and the following year.

FUTU's crypto-focused expansion initiatives might have taken a setback.

Barclays (BCS) issued a note (not publicly available) titled "Seeking A Path To Riches" on July 17, 2025. The bank's research indicated that FUTU is "one of the leading applicants" for "licenses to issue stablecoins in HK."

The company was asked about the "crypto (stablecoin) exchange license in Hong Kong" at its Q2 earnings call. It responded by saying that it is "in the Phase 2 of the VATP (Virtual Asset Trading Platform) license application in Hong Kong" and "doing the feasibility studies for more license applications in other markets."

I think it is reasonable to infer that FUTU is actively exploring stablecoin-related opportunities, which could broaden its revenue base.

But "Financial Times" reported on Oct. 19 "PBoC (People’s Bank of China) officials advised against participating in the initial stablecoin rollout over concerns about allowing tech groups and brokerages to issue any type of currency." The same write-up also mentioned that "Chinese tech giants have paused plans to issue stablecoins in Hong Kong, after Beijing raised concerns."

It's highly possible that the implementation of new stablecoin legislation in HK is delayed. This takes into account the Chinese policymakers' unfavorable stance regarding crypto.

My view is that FUTU's long-term growth ceiling has become lower with the regulatory developments of late. Any stablecoin-related valuation premium is also no longer justified for the stock.

On the other hand, the firm's AUM growth could be hurt by China's greater scrutiny of taxation pertaining to overseas investments.

Legal firm "Morgan Lewis" highlighted in an Oct. 24 post that "the Chinese government has introduced a set of new regulations requiring internet platforms to report tax-related information." "Platforms providing services" like "brokerage" are among those affected by the updated rules.

Mainland Chinese have been keen on participating in the Hong Kong stock market. A major reason is because the city doesn't impose any levies on capital gains.

My thoughts are that the PRC's onshore investors might decide to turn their attention back to domestic equities listed in Shanghai/Shenzhen. FUTU's HK-listed financial products may be less popular going forward.

The consensus is already projecting that the company's EPS growth goes from +67% in 2025 to +15% for 2026 based on S&P Capital IQ data. The actual slowdown might be more severe with these adverse policy shifts.

My Closing Remarks

FUTU remains a hold-rated name. Its next 12 months' P/E is 18.3x (source: S&P Capital IQ).

The average forward earnings multiple for FUTU's peers UP Fintech (TIGR) and Interactive Brokers (IBKR) is 21x.

The stock's upside is +15% (21/18.3) pegged to its listed comparables. I require a capital appreciation of at least 20% to warrant a "Buy." It doesn't meet this criterion.

FUTU doesn't have clear-cut re-rating drivers. The potential Q3 beat is negated by policy-related headwinds.

data.title: Highwoods Properties: Beaten-Down Office REIT Poised For A Strong Comeback
data.description:
Introduction & Financials

Highwoods Properties, Inc. (HIW) is a REIT that focuses on developing and managing high-quality office properties mostly in the best US business districts. The stock has been very volatile for a REIT as a result of several factors that made the market’s sentiment drop, including headwinds from the remote/hybrid work trends, falling occupancy rates and lower AFFO, as well as rising interest rates, potentially opening an opportunity given their potential to recover.

During Q3, HIW improved their 2025 FFO outlook to $3.41 to $3.45 per share compared to the $3.37 to $3.45 per share expected before. Since they don’t provide anything further from the FFO, I’ll use a FCF adjusted for proceeds from sales, which comes at ~$270.32 million in the first 9 months of 2025 or roughly $360 million annualized, which is definitely a solid improvement compared to FY24’s $315.54 million, FY23’s $278.34 million and FY22’s $310.31 million.

HIW has also been consistently delivering solid per-share accretion, with 4.5% CAGR in CAD (Cash Available for Distribution) versus 2.6% CAGR in the average number of shares from 2010 to 2024, which is a very solid performance, although we can see a drop in CAD from 2021 as a result of the environment leading to a lower occupancy rates, higher costs of debt and overall weaker activity in the industry. It’s also worth mentioning that they expect a further drop in 2025 vs 2024, but the growth rate should remain solid.

As they say in the Q2 release, the company is undergoing some portfolio shifts, aiming to rotate out of slower-growth assets that are more CAPEX-intensive into higher-potential properties with better capital efficiency, while also capturing the “substantial NOI growth potential” in their operating portfolio and development pipeline. Looking at the longer term, we see $1.9 billion in acquisitions over the past 6 years compared to over $1.3 billion sold over the past 5 years, which is definitely a massive amount considering the company's size, although falling occupancy rates probably offset this for now, making a potential recovery even better.

One such move is the recent acquisition of the Legacy Union Parking Garage at 720 South Church Street in Charlotte for a $111.5 million total investment, supporting their owned Legacy Union office, whose customers represent ~70% of the annual revenue, leased on a long-term basis with a remaining contractual term of 9 years. Similarly, they closed the acquisition of the Advance Auto Parts, Inc. (AAP) Tower earlier this year for $138 million.

As they say, there is significant underlying upside in the company’s portfolio, with things like an improved occupancy ratio—which I’ll talk about below—as well as their development pipeline. I’ll continue on this point in the Risks & Opportunities section below, but overall we can see a solid pipeline of organic growth that should allow the company to develop even if it doesn’t focus on external acquisitions and instead only develops its own assets, which is a plus.

Financially, based on HIW’s latest earnings report, we can see a relatively normal position for a REIT, with little cash available but a ton of assets that offset the company’s debt, especially if we think about the net asset value which is very likely higher than the value recorded in the balance sheet.

As we can see, HIW also has no maturities until 2027, which should allow them to be patient for some quarters while interest rates get lower before refinancing. They also recently recast their $200 million unsecured bank term loan, extending its maturity from May 2026 to January 2029, at a rate of SOFR + 95 basis points, which is a significant improvement for their near-term liquidity.

Dividends & Buybacks

As a result of the stock’s volatility, the dividend yield now stands at ~6.76%, which is among the company’s higher levels. Right now, that’s about $215.7 million, which should be fine given their Adjusted FCF, getting to a roughly 60% payout based on my estimate for this year, so there is room for improvement although they seem to be extra cautious with it, which is smart given the current environment.

Risks & Opportunities

The number one near-term catalyst we have to keep in mind, especially for a REIT, will be rate cuts. Naturally, these have very significant effects, especially on REITs, being great for them in several ways. The effects of rate hikes/cuts are ultimately the reason behind the central bank’s decisions, made in an effort to steer the economy and fight inflation.

Again, I know this may seem like common knowledge for most of you, but I’m surprised by how many people I’ve seen (especially in recent months) that call REITs bad because they underperformed in recent years as rates were hiked. I like REITs as an asset class and I believe they can serve essential roles in many portfolios, so it’s a shame for someone to pass on these ideas thinking they’re bad just because they performed as they should in a high-rate environment. This is ultimately what this asset class is supposed to do because the business model is almost all about interest rates, basically playing with the spread between their cost of debt and return on their leases/investments—the difference being what they give back to us as shareholders, a bit of capital for investing/other uses.

So, not only do they reduce the interest expenses on the company’s debt (HIW’s interest expenses got to a record of ~$150 million TTM), having a direct impact on the company’s AFFO and other metrics, but they can also help the tenants in similar ways, providing improved financial flexibility in a time when many businesses need it.

Still, the market’s seems quite pessimistic around the US economy, although we’ve seen some improvements lately with Trump’s sanctions on Russia, India and China’s halt of Russian oil acquisitions, etc., but that’s more about global trade and we’re still looking at what is so far the second-largest government shutdown, huge levels of debt, renewed trade war fears, and more risks that can stem from these factors. For example, I see that the market is also worried that the shutdowns can result in less data for the Fed to base its interest rate decisions on, which can lead to an uncertain position as Powell may be inclined to go for a more careful approach, potentially affecting the expectations for 2 more rate cuts this year. And that’s on top of the significant political uncertainty felt in this environment, potentially leading to a bad or even worse scenario for this asset class.

This macro pressure is also felt in the company’s operations, with some of the lowest occupancy rates in recent history. Plus, this industry is also facing a headwind, with the work-from-home trends being a long-term threat to keep in mind, although we have to balance that with the company’s overall solid rent/NOI growth. We could be looking at some improvements if the economy also recovers, but that’s ultimately the key near-term uncertainty here.

Still, it’s true that the company is diversified in terms of tenants, geography and industry, with the top 20 tenants representing 28.4% of their annualized revenue, so they should also be relatively resilient in case any of these get into trouble. Not only that, but what that means is a higher potential to grow in case of a recovery, making the opportunity behind it more compelling if things go well.

Also, the trend in the industry's construction pipeline can be great for the company, as the high-rate environment and declining financial flexibility also came with less investments in new buildings. As the company’s portfolio centers around higher quality and solid areas, it’s also visible (top left) that their occupancy is still significantly better than the US/local averages, so it’s important to look at the broader picture.

Plus, Highwoods Properties also has a massive build-out pipeline, which can offer significant or at least steady long-term growth, allowing the company to focus on its own assets without having to worry about finding new acquisition targets to ramp up its growth.

Peer Comparison

Compared to a diverse set of peers including SL Green Realty Corp. (SLG), Brandywine Realty Trust (BDN), BXP, Inc. (BXP), Cousins Properties Incorporated (CUZ), Piedmont Realty Trust, Inc. (PDM) and Kilroy Realty Corporation (KRC), we see overall average valuation metrics, probably as a result of the company’s relatively solid quality and performance at a time when the industry is struggling.

Valuation

Annualizing the Adjusted FCF I mentioned earlier, we should be looking at about $360 million in 2025, and let’s assume a 5.5% CAGR over the first 5 years to consider potential occupancy improvements and rate cuts, as well as developments in their growth pipeline and asset recycling activities, with a 3.5% CAGR for the subsequent 5 years and a 2.25% terminal growth rate. I’ll assume a WACC of 7.5% (above my estimated ~7.21% based on a cost of equity of ~9% and 5.5% cost of debt), with $3.44 billion worth of net debt plus preferred on 110.52 million shares outstanding as of the Q3 report. This way, we get to an enterprise value of $8.19 billion, meaning an equity value of $4.75 billion, for a price of $42.98, basically getting us to the levels from before the rate hikes and industry’s slump began.

Conclusions

I rate HIW a Buy given their quality, good margin of safety, and solid performance despite the industry’s headwinds, while also providing a good dividend. Risk remains especially in this environment, but the company’s solid fundamentals and attractive price should offset it once rate cuts advance and the economy recovers.

data.title: German October Inflation Marks Start Of More Disinflation To Come
data.description:
By Carsten Brzeski, Global Head of Macro

Turning point! After several months of increasing headline inflation, the just-released inflation data points to a trend reversal. Headline inflation, according to the national measure, decreased to 2.3% year-on-year in October, from 2.4% YoY in September. The European measure also came down to 2.3% YoY. Core inflation remained unchanged at 2.8% YoY, while services inflation even increased somewhat to 3.5% YoY, from 3.4% YoY.

Moving towards 2%

The available regional state data shows that the drop in German inflation was mainly driven by favourable base effects. On the month, almost all categories saw prices slightly increase.

Looking ahead, the stronger euro and still-favourable energy base effects should push German inflation back towards - and below - 2% over the coming months. At the same time, the worsening labour market and AI will further moderate wage growth. Finally, US tariffs could also bring disinflationary pressures to Europe due to overcapacity and weaker sales in the US. While these elements clearly bring disinflationary forces to Germany over the coming months, the longer-term picture brings more upward pressure on inflation. Restructuring of supply chains, labour costs in an era of ageing and the green transition remain three important structural drivers of price pressures. And not to forget, the inflationary impact from Germany’s fiscal stimulus.

In short, today’s inflation reading marks another turning point and the start of at least a short-lived period of rather disinflationary pressures before inflationary forces take over again.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

data.title: American Century Emerging Markets Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Portfolio Review

Emerging markets ('EM') equities posted a double-digit third-quarter advance. EM stocks rallied and broadly outperformed developed markets as trade tensions generally subsided, the euphoria around artificial intelligence ('AI') persisted and expectations rose for more interest rate cuts from the U.S. Federal Reserve (Fed).

Chinese markets outperformed much of the globe. China posted some of the strongest returns, marking three straight months of outpacing its EM peers. Easing trade tensions with the U.S., policy support for chipmakers and accelerating spending on AI drove gains amid hopes that the government's policy to combat price wars and disinflation will help the Chinese economy.

Information technology stocks drove quarterly outperformance. The sector was home to three top contributors, including Zhongji Innolight, electronics manufacturing company Delta Electronics (OTCPK:DLEGF) and chip designer company Montage Technology. We believe Delta rallied amid positive earnings surprises, strong performance in electric vehicles and data centers, and growth expectations around global electrification trends and AI infrastructure expansion.

Financials was an area of relative strength. Stocks we did not hold helped power gains in the sector.

Positioning in materials hindered relative performance. Lack of exposure to many sector names that we did not own was a key driver to underperformance, along with an underweight to South Africa-based mining group Gold Fields (GFI) relative to the benchmark.

Key Contributors

Zhongji Innolight. We believe a strong earnings report and artificial intelligence (AI)-driven demand supported the stock. Zhongji Innolight is a key supplier of high-end optical transceivers for AI data centers and 5G networks, a focus of global AI capital spending cycles.

Delta Electronics. Positive earnings surprises and strong performance in electric vehicles and data centers lifted shares. The company raised earnings forecasts, reflecting confidence in its growth trajectory. We believe Delta, a key supplier of AI power, is benefiting from global electrification trends and AI infrastructure expansion.

Montage Technology. The company reported surging revenue and net profit growth, and our research indicated that it has continued to enlarge its presence in the scale-up networking market, while maintaining stable growth in its interface integrated circuit business.

Key Detractors

Xiaomi. We believe the stock was weak amid competition in the smartphone space, a seasonal slowdown in the Internet of Things segment and rising costs, as higher-than-expected operating expenses weighed on earnings. Our research also indicated that a slower-than-expected new factory ramp-up drove lower volume forecasts for electric vehicles.

ICICI Bank (IBN). The stock underperformed due to what we believed was a mix of margin pressure, rising gross nonperforming assets and concerns about consumer credit demand and asset quality. Net interest margin declined, and management warned that margins may fall further if interest rates fall. Deposit growth was also weaker than anticipated.

Alibaba (BABA) Group Holding. An underweight to the China-based e-commerce giant relative to the benchmark weighed on returns as the stock advanced during the period.

Notable Trades

Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (OTCPK:HKXCF). The securities and derivatives exchange is the key conduit of capital flows to and from mainland China. With policy support for capital markets activity and area economies driving flow activity, we believe increased initial public offering activity and the Stock Connect program reforms will likely support the stock.

Montage Technology. The company is a fabless firm mainly engaged in designing and selling memory interface chips, with end markets focused on servers and data centers. We believe solid growth in memory interface chips and a fast ramp-up of new products have helped create a more promising growth outlook for Montage Technology.

China State Construction International Holdings (OTCPK:CCOHF). We exited CSCI amid what we believed were ongoing challenges in China's construction and infrastructure space, including slower project approvals and continuing weakness in the real estate market.

BYD (OTCPK:BYDDF). We exited BYD amid what we believed were weaker-than-expected earnings, slowing domestic demand and intensifying competition in China's electric vehicle market. BYD missed consensus profit estimates and cut its 2025 sales target as government pressure to end aggressive price wars, which had helped fuel BYD's rapid growth, weighed on the company.

Portfolio Positioning

The portfolio continues to invest in companies where we believe financials are strong and improving but share price performance does not fully reflect these factors.

Our outlook remains constructive. In our view, emerging markets (EM) equities have been supported by strong company performance, stabilizing U.S. trade policy and anticipated interest rate cuts from the U.S. Fed. We believe the growth gap between EM and developed markets (DM) will remain robust, with EM economies' growth rates expected to improve in 2026, while the U.S. and some other DM are projected to weaken.

EM valuations, earnings growth potential provide separation. We believe EM companies typically offer more attractive valuations and the prospect of higher earnings growth than many global DM peers. Given the often strong inverse relationship between EM equities and the dollar, we think a weaker U.S. dollar could also function as a growth driver for EM.

Government policy efforts a key in China. The summer tariff pause between the U.S. and China has helped improve market sentiment toward China. We think that while domestic economic growth may moderate in the short term, the Chinese government's targeted approach to increasing domestic demand will likely support profitability, while easing deflation and oversupply. We believe that if the government is successful, demand improvement could be sizable and would likely reverberate across other emerging markets.

EM companies are central to global technology and artificial intelligence (AI) supply chains. Our research has indicated that while high tariff rates may provide headwinds in markets such as India and Brazil, South Korea, China and Taiwan are among the nations that have benefited from rapidly increasing investment in AI and AI-driven sentiment, pushing equities to all-time highs in many markets. During the quarter, many of the world's largest tech firms—hyperscalers including Alphabet ((GOOG) (GOOGL)), Amazon (AMZN), Meta Platforms (META) and Microsoft (MSFT)—revealed plans to increase their capital expenditures, affirming their commitment to AI-related spending despite some investor concerns that they might dial things back, especially in early 2025.

Goal and Strategy: Long-term capital growth by investing primarily in emerging market companies of all sizes.
